entry.title: Random Numbers and Probability Distributions in the ABAP Environments for 2508
entry.content:
Random Numbers and Probability Distributions in the ABAP Environments for 2508

1 Introduction

Can ABAP generate random numbers? If you're nodding yes, you're in the right place.

Most ABAP developers would instinctively say "yes"â€”after all, who hasn't used CL_ABAP_RANDOM for generating test data? But if you've ever looked under the hood, you'll know that not all random numbers are created equal. Every random number generator is tied to a probability distribution.

Here's the twist: Until now, ABAP only spoke the language of uniform randomnessâ€”a far cry from the rich, varied distributions that reflect real-world and business data.

The great news? With the latest ABAP releases, the answer has changed. ABAP now speaks the whole language of probability, supporting versatile random number generation for your advanced business needs!

It also has all the functionality to compute with probabilities. Just enough to make ABAP your probability workbench for every day's use.

Note: currently planned to be available on-premise and in the private cloud with the upcoming major SAP S/4HANA release in 2025. Please note that this plan is subject to change by SAP without prior notice.

2 Example: Customer Payment Date

Suppose you want to generate realistic data for customer payment dates. Do you imagine that customers pay at random, with every date being equally likely?

Of course not!

In reality, most customers settle their bills close to the due date, with a few paying a bit early or late, and only a handful paying extremely early or well past the deadline.

These patterns can be captured with various probability distributions, such as normal, beta, or exponential distributions. If you treat payment dates as discrete events, distributions like Poisson or multinomial may also fit.

For simplicity, we'll focus on the most common and versatile: the normal distribution. The normal distribution's importance comes from a deep and beautiful mathematical result, the central limit theorem. Simply put, it says:

If you average many independent random processesâ€”even if each one follows a different patternâ€”their average or sum will tend to form the familiar bell-shaped curve known as the normal distribution.

In short, the normal distribution is the most important probability distribution. 

Probability density of the normal distribution

The curve means that the normal distribution generates values around its mean value (here: zero) more often and values farther away less frequently. This can easily be adjusted to give a more realistic simulation of customer payment dates.

The ABAP code is surprisingly easy compared to other programming languages. It uses the new system class CL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION and its method NEXT_RANDOM_NUMBER( ). This class needs an underlying uniform random number generator given by an interface IF_ABAP_RANDOM. The old class CL_ABAP_RANDOM happens to implement IF_ABAP_RANDOM.

class payment_date_generator definition.
  public section.
    methods constructor importing rng type ref to if_abap_random. " new as well
    methods generate_payment_date importing due_date type d
                                  returning value(payment_date) type d.

  private section.
    data m_rng type ref to if_abap_random.
    data m_system_date type d.
    data m_distribution type ref to if_abap_prob_distribution.
endclass.

class payment_date_generator implementation.
  method constructor.
    m_rng = rng.
    m_system_date = cl_abap_context_info=>get_system_date( ).
    m_distribution = cl_abap_prob_distribution=>get_normal_distribution(
      mean = 0
      standard_deviation = 15 ). " 68% are within Â±15 days around due date
  endmethod.

  method generate_payment_date.
    while payment_date < m_system_date.
      payment_date = due_date + 
         conv i( m_distribution->next_random_number( rng = m_rng ) ).
    endwhile.
  endmethod.
endclass.

Using the new interface IF_ABAP_RANDOM, you can also plug in your own uniform random number generator. No need to take the ABAP one (just in case you need a cryptographically secure, normally distributed number). Using ABAP's CL_ABAP_RANDOM is faster, as special optimizations apply here.

Running the example on 2025/08/06 with due date 2025/08/20 and 1000 numbers gives the following histogram, for example:

Note: Although the normal distribution is symmetric around the mean value, we arrived at a non-symmetric distribution by "cutting off" the dates before the current date. This is called rejection sampling, and it gives a totally new probability distribution, unique to this business problem.

Implementation: There are two ABAP classes:

ClassDescriptionHint
CL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTIONCalculate with F (= FLOAT) probabilitiesFaster, more distributions
CL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION_DF34Calculate with DECFLOAT34 probabilitiesMuch slower, fewer distributions

By default, the classes CL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION and CL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION_DF34 generate F or DECFLOAT34 numbers, but they can easily be cast to P, I, or other datatypes in different scenarios.

Both classes can generate I (= INT4) or INT8 random numbers for discrete distributions by default using separate methods.

3 Supported probability distributions

In the ABAP environments 2508, the following distributions are supported:

DistributionTypeCL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION
(FLOAT Probabilities)		CL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION_DF34
(DECFLOAT34 Probabilities)		Business Example
Normal distributionContinuousYesYesCustomer satisfaction scores, Employee performance, and financial returns follow a normal distribution.
Lognormal distributionContinuousYesYesRevenue or units sold across a product catalog often follow a lognormal distribution. 
Exponential distributionContinuousYesYesThe duration of customer service calls can be modeled using an exponential distribution.
Gamma distributionContinuousYesYesA gamma distribution can model the time it takes to complete a project and the distribution of customer lifetime values (CLV) in CRM.
Chi-Squared distributionContinuousYesYesTest whether the customer prefers a new product feature over an existing one using the famous chi-squared test, which utilizes the chi-squared distribution.

Uniform-int/int8 distribution

Discrete

YesYes

Companies often conduct customer surveys in market research to gather feedback and insights. To ensure that the survey results represent the entire customer base, a uniform integer distribution can be used for random sampling.

Poisson distributionDiscreteYesNoUnderstanding customer traffic is crucial for staffing and operational decisions in retail management. The Poisson distribution can model the number of customers arriving at a store within a specific time interval.
Binomial distributionDiscreteYesNo

In manufacturing, the binomial distribution can be used to model the number of defective items (failures) in a sample of produced items.

Student's t-distributionContinuousYesNoUsing the famous t-test and the t-distribution, one can test whether a new marketing campaign significantly affected sales.
Hypergeometric distributionDiscreteYesNoIn inventory management, the hypergeometric distribution can be used to model the selection of items for inspection or audit from a finite inventory.
Geometric distributionDiscreteYesNoModel the number of customer interactions needed until the first sales occur.

Note:  More probability distributions might evolve in future ABAP releases (not an official statement, no guarantee, no promise or roadmap item). Please note that this plan is subject to change by SAP without prior notice.

4 Calculating with probabilities

These new classes aren't just about rolling random numbersâ€”they unlock many possibilities! Now you can compute probabilities, dive into advanced statistical analyses, and so much more.

The magic happens through the IF_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION interface, which lets you calculate cumulative distribution functions (CDFs), quantiles, and a range of other powerful statistical operations. Plus, with dedicated sub-interfaces for discrete distributions, you get even more specialized tools right at your fingertips.

Here we only talk about two very important methods:

MethodDescription
CDF (Cumulative Distribution Function)Calculates the probability that the distribution assumes values <= x. In mathematical terms: P(X <= x).
QuantileInverse of the CDF. The quantile function gives the smallest valueâ€¯xâ€¯ such that the cumulative probability (CDF) is at leastâ€¯p.

Business Problem for the CDF: What proportion of the bills are paid within 20 days of the due date?
Solution in ABAP: 

 

  final(dist) =
    cl_abap_prob_distribution=>get_normal_distribution( mean = 0 standard_deviation = 15 ).
  final(proportion) = dist->cdf( 20 ).
  cl_demo_output=>display( proportion ).

 

Business Problem for the Quantile: You want to know when 95% of customers have paid their bills.
Solution in ABAP:

  data quantile type d.
  final(dist) =
    cl_abap_prob_distribution=>get_normal_distribution( mean = 0 standard_deviation = 15 ).
  final(quantile_int) = conv i( ceil( dist->quantile( '0.95' ) ) ).
  quantile = due_date + quantile_int.  
  cl_demo_output=>display( quantile ).

This prints 2025/09/14 in my example from above, i.e., in mid-September, 95% of the customers paid their bill (simplified calculation for demo purposes, which does not account for the rejection sampling method applied above. Special applause to anyone posting the solution for the truncated normal distribution in the comments below.)

Note that many valid statistical methods can be used to find the correct probability distribution for your business problem. These can also be implemented now in ABAP.  

5 More Trivia

With the new classes, you can also do funny stuff, which is not quite new, but was difficult or slow before.

5.1 Generate many random numbers at once

Usually, you do not want to generate only one random number. You want to generate many random numbers. In the past, every generated random number was a single method call.

Example:

  types i_tab type standard table of i with empty key.
  final(rng) = cl_abap_random=>create( ).
  final(tab) = reduce i_tab( init _tab = value #( ) 
                             for i = 1 then i + 1 until i > 1000
                             next _tab = value #( base _tab ( rng->int( ) ) ) ).

This is slow, as we have 1000 method calls and a FOR-LOOP.

Now, this can be sped up many times by doing the loop inside the ABAP kernel.

  final(rng) = cl_abap_random=>create( ).
  final(distrib) = cl_abap_prob_distribution=>get_uniform_int_distribution( range = value #( ) ). " empty range => all numbers
  final(tab) = distrib->next_random_numbers( count = 1000 rng = rng ).

  cl_demo_output=>display( tab ).

5.2 Analyzing range tables and generating random numbers in non-consecutive intervals

Another nice example is generating uniformly distributed integer random numbers in arbitrary subsets of the integers (i.e., not in a single contiguous interval). The constructor for the uniform integer distribution accepts a range table.

  data distrib type ref to if_abap_prob_distribution_int.
  final(rng) = cl_abap_random=>create( ).
  distrib = cl_abap_prob_distribution=>get_uniform_int_distribution(
    range = value #( ( sign = 'I' option = 'BT' low = 1 high = 10 )
                     ( sign = 'E' option = 'EQ' low = 5 ) ) ).
  cl_demo_output=>write( distrib->support_size( ) ).  " prints 9, i.e. we have 9 elements which are covered by the rangetab
  cl_demo_output=>write( distrib->median( ) ). " prints 6, which is the median of the set [1,2,3,4,6,7,8,9,10] in our definition  
  final(random_numbers) = distrib->next_random_numbers( count = 1000 rng = rng ). " generate random numbers from 1 to 10 excluding 5
  cl_demo_output=>display( random_numbers ).

Conclusion: You can easily generate random numbers that satisfy any condition specified by a range table. Keep in mind that the range table is treated as a setâ€”so overlapping conditions like X < 6 and X < 7 simply combine to X < 7. Values that fall into both ranges (such as 5) are not given extra weight or counted multiple times.

Also, integers are "cut off" at the minimum/maximum INT4 or INT8 value, so you can't compute uniform discrete probabilities of an infinite set. Mathematics is safe here.

6 Overflows

When generating random numbers, a probability distribution can overflow. The normal distribution, for example, spans the whole real line. As FLOAT's value range is finite, this can lead to unexpected results for very large mean or standard deviation, or, if you are just "unlucky", also for small ones. 

We decided that random number generation should never overflow. We achieve this by two means:

    1.  Restricting the parameters for the distribution in the constructor to "sensible" values reflecting real-world scenarios.
    2.  If you are unlucky anyhow, use rejection sampling until we are in the float range. 

This is an important compromise and something that is not done in most random number generator libraries. It also means that the distribution may not exactly be (normally-, gamma-, ...) distributed at the borders of the float or decfloat range. This has no influence on any real-world scenario or calculation, however. 

On the contrary, you can be content that no overflow occurs, ever. This is an important feature of a random number generator. 

7 Conclusion

This article showcased the new ABAP capabilities for generating random numbers from various probability distributionsâ€”and performing probability calculationsâ€”using the powerful system classes CL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION and CL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION_DF34.

8 The interface IF_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION

For reference, here is the complete interface IF_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION with the implemented methods:

"! <p>Interface representing a probability distribution with probabilities of type F (=FLOAT). Used by class
"!  {@link CL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION }, which represents a probability distribution over the real line.</p>
interface if_abap_prob_distribution
  public .

  "! Table type to hold a collection of random numbers.
  types random_numbers type standard table of f with empty key.

  "! Returns the support of the probability distribution
  "! @parameter kind | The kind of support the distribution provides.
  methods support_kind
    returning value(kind) type if_abap_prob_types=>support_kind.

  "! Returns the kind of probability distribution
  "! @parameter kind | The kind of the distribution.
  methods distribution_kind
    returning value(kind) type if_abap_prob_types=>distribution_kind.

  "! Returns whether the probability distribution is continuous
  "! @parameter continuous | Flag indicating if the distribution is continuous.
  methods is_continuous
    returning value(continuous) type abap_bool.

  "! Returns the mean of the probability distribution
  "! @parameter mean | The mean value of the distribution.
  "! @raising CX_ABAP_PROB_UNSUPPORTED | if distribution has no mean
  methods mean
    returning value(mean) type f
    raising   cx_abap_prob_unsupported.

  "! Returns a possible mode of the probability distribution
  "! @parameter mode | The mode of the distribution.
  "! @raising CX_ABAP_PROB_UNSUPPORTED | if distribution has no mode
  methods mode
    returning value(mode) type f
    raising   cx_abap_prob_unsupported.

  "! Returns the variance of the probability distribution
  "! @parameter variance | The variance of the distribution.
  "! @raising CX_ABAP_PROB_UNSUPPORTED | if distribution has no variance
  methods variance
    returning value(variance) type f
    raising   cx_abap_prob_unsupported.

  "! Returns the (CDF-based) median of the probability distribution. Here, the median
  "! is the smallest x in the support, such that P(X <= x) >= 0.5.
  "! @parameter median | The median value of the distribution.
  methods median
    returning value(median) type f.

  "! Returns the cumulative distribution function, i.e. the probability that the
  "! distribution assumes values <= arg.
  "! @parameter arg                      | The argument for which to calculate the cumulative distribution function.
  "! @parameter probability              | P( X <= arg )
  "! @raising cx_sy_arithmetic_overflow  | If an arithmetic overflow occurs.
  "! @raising cx_parameter_invalid_range | If the parameter is outside of the support.
  methods cdf
    importing arg                type f
    returning value(probability) type f
    raising   cx_sy_arithmetic_overflow
              cx_parameter_invalid_range.

  "! Returns the probability density function (if continuous) or the probability mass function
  "! (if not continuous)
  "! @parameter arg                      | The argument for which to calculate the probability density or mass function.
  "! @parameter value                    | The calculated density or mass value.
  "! @raising cx_sy_arithmetic_overflow  | If an arithmetic overflow occurs.
  "! @raising cx_parameter_invalid_range | If the parameter is outside of the support.
  methods pdf_or_pmf
    importing arg          type f
    returning value(value) type f
    raising   cx_sy_arithmetic_overflow
              cx_parameter_invalid_range.

  "! Returns the p-quantile of the the distribution,
  "! @parameter probability              | The probability for which to calculate the quantile. Should be
  "!                                       between 0 and 1.
  "! @parameter quantile                 | The calculated quantile value.
  "! @raising cx_parameter_invalid_range | If the parameter is out of range.
  "! @raising cx_sy_arithmetic_overflow  | If an arithmetic overflow occurs.
  methods quantile
    importing probability     type f
    returning value(quantile) type f
    raising   cx_parameter_invalid_range
              cx_sy_arithmetic_overflow.

  "! Returns the minimum value the distribution can assume.
  "! @parameter value | The minimum value in the distribution.
  methods min_value
    returning value(value) type f.

  "! Returns the maximum value the distribution can assume
  "! @parameter value | The maximum value in the distribution.
  methods max_value
    returning value(value) type f.

  "! Returns a random number distributed according to the distribution
  "! @parameter rng    | The random number generator to use.
  "!                     When rng is of type {@link CL_ABAP_RANDOM }, other algorithms are used
  "!                     which are significantly faster and generate different random numbers for some
  "!                     distributions.
  "! @parameter number | The next random number generated.
  methods next_random_number
    importing rng           type ref to if_abap_random
    returning value(number) type f.

  "! Returns an internal table of random number distributed according to the distribution
  "! @parameter count   | The number of random numbers to generate.
  "! @parameter rng     | The random number generator to use.
  "!                      When rng is of type {@link CL_ABAP_RANDOM }, other algorithms are used
  "!                      which are significantly faster and generate different random numbers for some
  "!                      distributions.
  "! @parameter numbers | A set of generated random numbers.
  methods next_random_numbers
    importing count          type i
              rng            type ref to if_abap_random
    returning value(numbers) type random_numbers.

endinterface.

entry.title: Devtoberfest 2025 Welcome!
entry.content:
We are thrilled to announce that Devtoberfest, an SAP TechEd event, returns this year running from September 29th - October 24th, 2025. It's a celebration for SAP developers and an excellent way to get ready for SAP TechEd. If you weren't around for Devtoberfest in 2020 -2024; here's a quick video overview of the event:

The Devtoberfest tracks have changed but no worries the new tracks are listed down below!

 
Iâ€™ll repeat the same overall description weâ€™ve used the past few years as it does an excellent job of capturing the spirit of the event:

Devtoberfest is an attempt to capture the experience of the pre-conference events, like SAP InnoJam of yearsâ€™ past. Itâ€™s an event which kicks off the SAP TechEd season. Devtoberfest takes some of the best aspects of the traditional hackathon type event, such as learning by building something, but opens the experience to the entire community and spreads across multiple weeks to better accommodate everyoneâ€™s busy schedules. Itâ€™s an event that is also designed for you to be able to participate asynchronously and on your own time schedule. As the idea formed, weâ€™ve seen an opportunity here to really build something that is truly a festival for developers.

Devtoberfest â€“ An open celebration of what makes us developers â€“ Coding and Collaboration!
 
Getting Started with Devtoberfest
 
You are in the right place.  The home for the event will again be this SAP Community Group - where you find yourself right now. There is this dedicated SAP Community Group for Devtoberfest and all the individual events will be listed in the SAP Community Events calendar.  

This means no registration on a third-party event site or having to manually link to your SAP Community account. You register for Devtoberfest by reviewing the legal terms and conditions posted in this group and then just joining the Devtoberfest group. If you already joined in 2022, 2023 or 2024, then you are ready to participate again this year. 
 
Continuing with a similar overall approach as the last two years, this Devtoberfest will be ripe with educational and enablement sessions, opportunities to get hands-on with new and evolving developer tools, and a wonderful way to get you ready for the upcoming SAP TechEd event.
 
And if you prefer a video tutorial on signing up for Devtoberfest:

Educational Content
The backbone of Devtoberfest remains the educational content sessions. Devtoberfest is still an event designed for asynchronous consumption. While we will release content every weekday during Devtoberfest, it's all intended that you consume the content on your own schedule.
 
This year's tracks are the following:

ðŸŸ¢ Monday â€“ ABAP

ðŸŸ£ Tuesday â€“ Tooling & Frontend

ðŸ”´Wednesday â€“ Integration

ðŸ”µThursday â€“ Data & AI

ðŸŸ  Friday â€“ CAP

ðŸŸ¡ All Week â€“ Fun Activities

 
Fun Activities
This is a celebration so the Fun Friday activities will return, somewhat. This year we are changing things up a bit. Instead of having a Fun Friday, we have lots of fun activities sprinkled in throughout the week! There will be pro-active fun activities but also community fun activities like Petoberfest happening over the span of Devtoberfest.
We saw the greatest amount of participation last year in the activities that didn't require you to show up at a specific time, so we will continue to utilize those kinds of activities this year.
 
For all the information on the Fun Activities: coming soon!
 
The Contest
2022 saw the introduction of the grand prize of the Winner's Retreat to Newport Beach and Disneyland. It was great fun and hugely successful. The 2023 winners were joining us at the SAP TechEd road show (ASUG Tech Connect) in November 2024 which was an amazing experience.

The winners of 2024 are joining us this year (2025) in Berlin for SAP TechEd to learn, and to engage with SAP and the community! Congratulations to our 2024 winners!
 
When something works that well, why change it up; so again this year the grand prize for Devtoberfest will be a similar retreat to a future SAP TechEd event (in 2026). 
 
For all the information on the Content - coming soon!
For the Contest Official Rules - Devtoberfest 2025 Contest Official Rules - SAP Community
And we have a prize FAQ - Devtoberfest 2025 Grand Prize Trip FAQ - SAP Community
 
Questions, Comments, or Feedback
Questions about the event? Or the judging? Or you have a follow up question after participating in one of the educational enablement sessions? For any question or comment related to Devtoberfest we ask that you please use the dedicated Devtoberfest Discussions board available here.
 
Legal Stuff
It wouldnâ€™t be any kind of event or contest without some legal content that Iâ€™m sure everyone will read in full detail. The legal terms and conditions for the 2025 event are coming soon.

entry.title: Re: Optimizing Data Action Script
entry.content:
Hi @nasser_itani 

The reason it takes 17 seconds to execute a single project is that the script contains five FOREACH statements. I believe the first "FOREACH [d/DIM_WBS_PROJECT]" statement is necessary, but for performance improvement, the remaining four FOREACH statements should be minimized.

The script contains many variables, and a corresponding FOREACH was executed to obtain the value of each variable. 

For performance improvement, Variables(INTEGER & FLOAT) and FOREACH statements should be minimized overall. However, the script optimization cannot be achieved solely based on the currently provided script. It appears that a comprehensive restructuring of the script is required.

Moonjun

entry.title: F4 value help for a field Determined by another field in RAP ABAP
entry.content:
Hi All , 

I have an RAP Application, displaying records . if i select multiple records from list report and click on custom button , it opens up a pop up having 2 fields ( 1st field - which  field will be updated in all selected records , 2nd filed - what would be the new value to be updated ) .
I have handled the pop up display with Abstract Entity .( having 2 fields , FLD1 , FLD2 ). In AB entity the FLD1 has attached with a F4 which will give me the list of fields  to choose which field to be changed in records, FLD2 will hold the new Value ) .

for ex- if in Pop up , FLD1 ( has values like Name, Age, Date,Gender,status  ) , and i select  FLD1 = Age and then in FLD2  = 50 then , Age field will be updated as 50 in all selected records in list . This is working fine .  

However i want to provide a Calendar  as F4 help in FLD2 when user selects FLD1 = Date . 

Example : FLD1 can have values  like Name, Age, Date, Gender, status  etc . so                             When FLD1 = AGE , then FLD2 = normal input field , but when FLD1 = DATE , then i want to add a F4 of calendar to FLD2 .  

Is there a way to handle this ?? In runtime i can get the value for FLD1 to know if its Date field or normal field . If its Date field, how to add a Calender as F4 to the FLD2 . 

Any Suggestions ??

entry.title: Re: MONITOR PURCHASE ORDER ITEM showing no data
entry.content:
Hello @JabinRubayat 

The issue where the Monitor Purchase Order Items (F2358) app is displaying no data. Below are the key checks and resolution steps.

Key Checks to me

Business Role Assignment

  • Ensure the user has the role SAP_BR_PURCHASER.
  • Verify catalog SAP_MM_BC_PO_MONITOR_PC is included.

Filter Settings

  • The app defaults to open & released POs only.
  • Draft, deleted, or completed POs will not appear.
  • Please broaden filters (supplier, purchasing org, company code) and search again.

Authorisation Restrictions

  • Business roles may restrict company codes, plants, or purchasing orgs.
  • Review value restrictions in Maintain Business Roles.

PO Status

  • Confirm in Manage Purchase Orders that the purchase orders are in Released status.
  • Newly created items may take time until the analytics refresh.

Possible Resolution Steps

  1.  Assign the SAP_BR_PURCHASER role to the user.
  2. Verify that the PO is in Released status.
  3. Run the application with all filters cleared.
  4. If there is still no data â†’ review business role restrictions..

Check and refer to the below helpful SAP Documentation

  • SAP Help Portal: Monitor Purchase Order Items (F2358)
  • KBA 2790959 - Monitor Purchase Order Items: display of Fully received & invoiced POs
  • 3493638 - Number is not shown when using filter Order Date then save as tile in Fiori Monitor Purchase Order Item app

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Govern Your RISE Project using CALM/ACTIVATE for Integration Suite, Edge Integration Cell
entry.content:
When implementing SAP Integration Suite, Edge Integration Cell in a RISE with SAP project, youâ€™ll quickly realize thereâ€™s more to it than just following the installation steps.
Multiple teams are involved â€” Basis, Integration, Security â€” and the process spans several weeks with dependencies, approvals, and testing.

Thatâ€™s where SAP Cloud ALM (CALM) and the SAP Activate methodology come in.
Instead of treating the setup guide as a static document, you can turn it into a living, governed project plan in CALM â€” giving you visibility, accountability, and structure.

In this blog, Iâ€™ll walk you through how we built a CALM project plan directly from the SAP Help guide:
Setting up and Managing Edge Integration Cell
â€¦ and aligned it with SAP Activate phases to ensure nothing slipped through the cracks.

Why Governance Matters for Edge Integration Cell

The Edge Integration Cell extends your Integration Suite into on-premise or private cloud environments, ideal for hybrid integration scenarios.
But without governance:

  • Prerequisite checks get missed.
  • Network and security tasks are delayed.
  • The â€œwho does whatâ€ question slows progress.

Using CALM + Activate solves these issues:

  • Phased approach (Prepare â†’ Explore â†’ Realize â†’ Deploy â†’ Run)
  • Task ownership and clear accountability
  • Built-in dependencies and milestone tracking

Building the CALM Project Plan from the SAP Help Guide

The SAP Help guide breaks the setup into logical sections â€” installation prerequisites, network configuration, deployment, operations.
We mirrored this structure in CALM:

  • Each section became a Work Package.
  • Each step in the guide became a Task, with an owner, due date, and link to the original help page.


The Edge Integration Cell setup as a governed CALM project â€” each work package represents a major setup step from SAP Help.


Detailed CALM task view â€” each task links directly to the relevant SAP Help step, ensuring consistent execution.

Example:

  • Work Package: Install Edge Integration Cell
    • Task: Prepare installation environment (linked to SAP Help section)
    • Task: Run installation script on target host
    • Task: Validate installation logs

Using SAP Activate in CALM

Once the work packages were in place, we assigned them to Activate phases:

  • Prepare: Check system prerequisites, plan network connectivity
  • Explore: Review architecture, finalize sizing & connectivity models
  • Realize: Perform installation, apply configurations
  • Deploy: Prepare go-live, complete handover documentation
  • Run: Set up monitoring, operational processes


Phase view in CALM shows the progression of the Edge Integration Cell setup across Activate stages.

Practical Tips for Making It Work

Through experience, these points made the biggest difference:

  1. Assign clear task owners â€” CALM Personas ensure accountability
  2. Use dependencies â€” Ensure network setup tasks finish before installation begins.
  3. Link every CALM task to the exact SAP Help step â€” removes ambiguity.
  4. Review progress at each Activate phase gate â€” prevents issues from snowballing.

Conclusion

By combining CALM project planning with the SAP Activate methodology, you can transform the Edge Integration Cell setup from a static instruction list into a clear, collaborative, and governable project.

Whether youâ€™re in a RISE project or a hybrid integration scenario, this approach ensures:

  • Everyone knows their tasks.
  • Steps happen in the right order.
  • Stakeholders can track progress in real-time.

If you need support on your SAP Integration Suite, Edge Cell journey, feel free to reach out to us via: SAP Integration Modernization <integration.modernization@sap.com>

entry.title: Error "Missing Customizing in table TFK028G (CAMT053 PMNTRCDTESCT H)" in FPB7 (RKKKKA00)
entry.content:
Dear all,

the error: â€œMissing Customizing in table TFK028G (CAMT053 PMNTRCDTESCT H).â€œ occurs in SAP S/4HANA On Premise System X client Y (S4CORE 106), when carrying out the transaction FPB7 (report RFKKKA00) to transfer relevant data of an electronic bank account statement (EBS) to FS-CD (FI-CA), particularly for creating a Payment Lot or a Return Lot, which contains all EBS header and item information.

Previously, the EBS has been created by importing an appropriate camt.053 XML file using the transaction FF_5.

According to the error message, an â€œHâ€ is expected that might reference to the field â€œFEBEP-EPVOZ: Debit/Credit Key for Line Items (for Bank Purposes)â€. This field is populated correctly in table FEBEP with an â€œHâ€ or â€œSâ€ depending on the item and its Business Transaction Code.

But:

In the FS-CD (FI-CA) Customizing â€œDefine Transactions for Electronic Bank Statement Transferâ€, View V_TFK028G, only entries â€“ especially regarding the field TFK028G-VOZPM â€“ can be maintained, which exist in the related FI-BL Bank Accounting Customizing ðŸ¡ª Business Transactions ðŸ¡ª Payment Transactions ðŸ¡ª Electronic Bank Statement: â€œMake Global Settings for Electronic Bank Statementâ€ ðŸ¡ª section â€œCreate Transaction Typeâ€ CAMT053 ðŸ¡ª â€œAssign External Transaction Types to Posting Rulesâ€:

ACMTACOPINTR              -
ACMTMDOPINTR            -
PMNTICDTAUTT              -
PMNTICDTBOOK             -
PMNTICDTDMCT             -
PMNTICDTPRCT               -
PMNTICDTRRTN              +
PMNTRCDTESCT              -
PMNTRCDTVCOM           -

There is no â€œSâ€ or â€œHâ€ as an attribute of the External Transaction Type in view field V_T028G-VOZPM (respective table field T028G-VOZPM), but as listed an â€œ-â€œ or â€œ+â€.

Many thanks in advance for your support to avoid this issue in advance, or to solve the problem that causes this error (e.g. by an installation-specific function module maybe, in FI-CA / FS-CD event 953).

Kind regards,
Jochem

entry.title: Bringing Back Badges to Reward Q&A Experts!
entry.content:
If youâ€™ve been a long-time member of SAP Community, youâ€™ve probably accumulated several badges over the years. Even newer members may have earned the basic one-time badges available on our current platform â€“ such as the badge for taking our tutorial and the various badges awarded for a first-time action (e.g., replying, leaving a kudo). Members havenâ€™t, however, been able to receive ongoing recognition for repeated activity.

That will change starting tomorrow (Tuesday, August 19).

With our previous gamification system, we rewarded badges for posting quality content, providing helpful answers, and more â€“ giving members the opportunity to earn multiple awards for frequent participation. (As an example, take a look at my list of badges â€“ which pales compared to the accomplishments of veterans who have been around since the earliest days of our online community!) As of August 19, weâ€™re bringing this recognition back, starting with progression badges based on the number of answers accepted as solutions.

If you like answering questions (and youâ€™re gifted at helping other members find solutions to their problems), then youâ€™ve probably already received the first badge in this new series â€“ by giving an answer that was accepted as a solution. Now you can earn an additional four badges, depending on the number of solutions you provided in Q&A.

Weâ€™ll be rewarding people retroactively, so depending on your Q&A activity and length of community membership (going back to previous community platforms), you may get one or more badges tomorrow.

Not sure of your numbers? You can find them in your community content area. After logging in, click on the person icon in the upper right of any community page, then select â€œMy content.â€

Youâ€™ll see your total number of answers in the Private Stats section at the bottom of your â€œMy contentâ€ area.

But remember: an answer is not a solution. An answer becomes a solution when someone accepts it as the correct answer to a question. Youâ€™ll find your total number of solutions in the gray box at the top of your â€œMy contentâ€ page.

So in this example, this member should expect to get all four of the new solutions badges. With 93 solutions, he has achieved the necessary criteria for the second badge (2 solutions), third badge (5 solutions), fourth badge (25 solutions), and the fifth and final badge in this progression series (50 solutions). (I sure hope heâ€™s reading this, so he wonâ€™t wonder whatâ€™s going on when he sees four badge notifications tomorrow.)

With this new badge set, SAP Community is once again acknowledging the awesome members who regularly contribute quality content. And weâ€™re not stopping here! In the near future, we plan to introduce other progression sets. We donâ€™t want to give away too much information just yet â€“ we thought it would be fun to keep things a surprise â€“ but we do encourage you to get more active, as you may find yourself receiving bigger badge payoffs very soon.

Make sure to monitor the Whatâ€™s New section for announcements about the new progression badge sets as they become available. In the meantime, if you frequently participate in the community, keep up the good work. Or if youâ€™re more of a lurker, consider jumping in and building up the numbers necessary for badges. Depending on what you do (and what youâ€™ve done), you may find yourself the recipient of several shiny new badges as we extend the ways in which we show appreciation for those who make our community a better place!

OK, one hint: We arenâ€™t just going to reward the members active in Q&A, so if answering questions isnâ€™t your thing, you can still gain badges for other activities. Experiment with meaningful contributions, show your support for other members, and see what happens!

entry.title: Re: Clear Salary outside HireDate and TerminationDate ranges, and calculate per day salary
entry.content:
So I split the code into two and it works now

CONFIG.HIERARCHY.INCLUDE_MEMBERS_NOT_IN_HIERARCHY = [d/Account], [d/CostCenter], [d/Emp_Status], [d/Employee], [d/LegalEntity], [d/Location]
CONFIG.GENERATE_UNBOOKED_DATA = ON

MEMBERSET [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC"
MEMBERSET [d/Account] = "ACC_017"
MEMBERSET [d/DataSource] = "DS_PAYROLL"
MEMBERSET [d/Employee] = (BASEMEMBER([d/Employee].[h/EmpStatus], "ACTIVE", "TERMINATED", "TO_BE_HIRED", "INACTIVE"))

// Hire Date Proration
IF DATEDIFF([d/HireDate], [d/Date], "MONTH") < 0 THEN
    DATA([d/Account] = "ACC_017", [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC", [d/DataSource] = "DS_PAYROLL") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC") * 0
ELSE
    IF DATEDIFF([d/HireDate], [d/Date], "DAY") < 0 THEN
        DATA([d/Account] = "ACC_017", [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC", [d/DataSource] = "DS_PAYROLL") =
            (1 - ABS(DATEDIFF([d/HireDate], [d/Date], "DAY")) / DAYSINMONTH([d/Date])) * RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC")
    ELSE
        // Full month if hired before this month
        DATA([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC")
    ENDIF
ENDIF

Here is the code for reference, Thanks @William_Yu1 and @Chuma for trying to help me.

entry.title: Re: CDS Hierarchy Directory: How to use NOTASSIGNEDNODE Annotation to suppress or to filter the Not
entry.content:
Hi 

you can try  @AnalyticsDetails.query.hierarchySettings.childNodePosition: #ABOVE to specify child node  position to upwards.

 

and Following is the table defination for zoq_connid_hd -

@EndUserText.label : 'Hierarchy directory for ConnectionID (SFLIGHT)'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #ALLOWED
define table zoq_connid_hd {

  key hieid    : zoq_conhieid not null;
  hiertxt      : rstxtlg;
  last_changed : rstimestmp;

}

I hope it helps.

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite - Operations â€“ A Structured Blog Series
entry.content:
This blog series is designed to provide a structured overview of operational best practices within SAP Integration Suite. It aims to support in establishing transparency, stability, and modernization across integration landscapes. Each entry focuses on a specific operational domain, offering actionable guidance for sustainable Integration Suite management. 

When it comes to operational best practices, several key areas are particularly relevant for ensuring a smooth, efficient, and scalable integration landscape.
The following aspects have been identified as key priorities, and this series aims to provide targeted guidance for each, including best practices from daily consulting business.*

*The current selection is based on our daily challenges and requests. We reserve the right to expand the scope with additional topics or adjust priorities as needed. Miss something â€“ say something. 

 

AreaSummary and IntentionLink
Architecture and Setup
  • Tenant Landscape (Account Setup according to BTP Guidance Framework)
  • tbd.
tbd. 
Security and Compliance
  • User Role Management: Establish a clear authorization model, assigning roles such as Developer, AMS, and others.
  • Authentication & Authorization
  • Access Policies
  • Security Monitoring (Leverage tools like SAP Enterprise Threat Detection to track audit and access logs, ensuring compliance and traceability)
  1. Streamlining User Management
  2. ...
 

Lifecycle Management

  • CI/CD for Integration Suite (Maintain version control for integration artifacts and automate deployments across environments (CI/CD))
  • Version Control
  • Integration Suite API's
tbd. 

Change Management & Quality Assurance

  • SAP Cloud Transport Management (Establish a structured transport mechanism using SAP Cloud Transport Management Service (CTMS).)
  • SAP Integration Suite - Naming Conventions
  • SAP Integration Suite Design Guidelines
tbd.

Monitoring and Troubleshooting

  • Message monitoring (iFlows, APIs, adapters, SAP Application Interface Framework (AIF))
  • Alerting setup (email, webhook, SAP Alert Notification Service)
  • Integration with SAP Cloud ALM or external tools
  • Implement detailed logging and trace capabilities for root cause analysis e.g. known Error Database
tbd. 
Miscellaneous Topics
  • Interface Repository (Setting up a centralized interface repository, e.g., with LeanIX or a tool of your choice)
  • SAP Integration Suite Ai capabilities
  • SAP Integration Suite Expert Portal
  • ...
tbd.

Join the Conversation 

SAP Integration Suite is redefining enterprise integration by breaking down silos and connecting diverse systems across the business. Whether you're managing an SAP-centric landscape or a hybrid IT environment, its 360-degree Suite approach offers a comprehensive toolset for end-to-end integration and drives business innovation.

Weâ€™d love to hear your thoughts and experiences with SAP Integration Suite. What challenges are you facing? How can we help you unlock the full potential of your IT ecosystem? 

Feel free to use the comment section or reach out to us via SAP Integration Services.

Modernize. Integrate. Innovate.

entry.title: Re: What's the best way to see material stock and history...
entry.content:
Greetings @marceloromeiro !

 

For a list of available CDS view related to Stock and Material Documents, I highly recommend checking the information present in the following section of the help portal:

CDS Views for Stock and Material Documents | SAP Help Portal

There, you can review which CDS view fits best for your business requirements!

 

 

Additionally, In S/4 Hana Cloud ERP, there is an app called Stock - Single Material (App ID: F1076), which, in its functionalities, include:

 

  • Display a stock overview of a single material.

  • Compare the stock information with the safety stock and minimum safety stock values defined for the material.

  • Detailed stock history for each plant or storage location for the last 11 periods (period-end closing) and the stock balance at the reporting date.

 

The stock history is structured as an interactive chart that allows you to analyze it in a visual way.

To review a stock, first select a material. The app displays your stock of the material by plant and by storage location as a table. It displays the stock history of the last 11 calendar months and the current stock in a curve diagram. The app uses todayâ€™s date as the reporting date. You can change the reporting date. If you leave the Reporting Date field empty, the system displays the stock of material for the current period (end of period).  To display your stock by plant and by storage location in a bar diagram, choose the graphical view.

The Stock History column or some stock types might be hidden. In the personalization area, you can specify the columns that you want the system to display in the results list. You access the stock history of all visible stock in the table by clicking on the micro chart.

 

If you wish to get an analysis of multiple materials, check app Stock - Multiple Materials (App ID: F1595), which contains information such as:

  • Advanced Search Capabilities

    Various filter options for searching large amounts of data specifically for the required materials. With these filter options you can better investigate your active materials (that is, for which goods movements have taken place) and materials without a deletion indicator in more detail.

  • Display a stock overview of one or multiple materials.

  • Display the value of your stock.

  • Display additional storage location information, for example, storage bin.

  • Display the carbon footprint of the materials in your plant.

The app calculates the stock values based on the stock quantity of the selected reporting date multiplied by the current material price. This means that the app always calculates using the current material price, irrespective of the reporting date you have selected. This calculation method for the stock value is common to all Fiori apps in Inventory Management.

In addition, in the Stock - Multiple Materials app, you can display the result of a calculation method based on the historical prices at the time of the related material postings.

Note that these two calculation methods lead to different results. SAP recommends that you use the main calculation method based on the current material price, because this method leads to faster results and is optimized for stock analysis.

 

I highly recommend checking the documentation for both applications for additional information regarding this subject:

Stock - Single Material app:

Stock - Single Material | SAP Help Portal

Stock - Multiple Materials app:

Stock - Multiple Materials | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: Re: How Other VAT Reg. No. is determined in Billing?
entry.content:
Additional VAT numbers in KNAS-STCEG (e.g., NLâ€¦, FRâ€¦) via the â€œOtherâ€ button in the customer master are valid for cross-border transactions where the customer is registered in multiple EU countries but does not have separate addresses.

Let us say an example - Your customer is based in Germany (main VAT: DEâ€¦). Theyâ€™re also VAT-registered in the Netherlands and France (NLâ€¦, FRâ€¦). You ship goods to NL or FR, but the customer doesnâ€™t have a separate Ship-to address there. In this case, you donâ€™t need to create new Ship-to customers for NL or FR. You simply maintain the NL and FR VAT numbers in KNAS-STCEG, and configure SAP to select the correct one based on the destination country.

entry.title: Behavior When 'Public Project' is Set to No in Customer Projects
entry.content:
***Image/data in this Blog is from SAP internal systems, sample data, or demo systems. Any resemblance to real data is purely coincidental.***

Over the past few years, we've received numerous inquiries about the behavior of setting 'Public Project' to No within a customer project in the "Plan Customer Projects" app. To address these questions, I conducted a test on our internal system using version CE2508 and have documented the observed behavior below.

Scenario 1:

User A: role SAP_BR_PROJECT_MANAGER_PROF is assigned without any restrictions.
User B: role SAP_BR_PROJECT_MANAGER_PROF is assigned without any restrictions.

User A creates a customer project CLCP202507 and sets 'Public Project' to No, meaning it is a private project.
When User B logs into the system, he is able to see and edit the private customer project, despite not being assigned any role within the project.

 

Scenario 2:

User A: role SAP_BR_PROJECT_MANAGER_PROF is assigned without any restrictions.
User B: role ZSAP_BR_PROJECT_MANAGER_PROF_DIA is assigned, set restriction on  'Confidential Project' as N under Project part for Read authorization. See below.

The same private customer project CLCP202507 and User B is not assigned as any role in the project.
When User B logs into the system, he is not able to see the private customer project, even when conducting a direct search using the project ID. Only the public project is displayed. See below.


Scenario 3:

With the same settings in the customer project and business roles as scenario 2.
Assign user B as Project Controller in private customer project CLCP202507.

User B logs in the system and is able to view both the private project and the public projects. See below.

entry.title: Re: How Can We Consume Standard APIs With Business Users...
entry.content:
Hi @ItsMeGopi ,

I am adding on top of @Chuma 's good answer.

It might be easy to understand this question using an analogy: in the on-premise world, business users need to access data from another system. He/she asks the IT department to build an integration to that system. After the integration is done, he/she accesses the data without knowledge how this is done. Fast forward to the current cloud world, we use API to build the integration between systems. The business users only need to give the requirement, IT guy (if still exists) builds the integration using API. Afterwards he/she just access the data like it is on the current cloud system, but should not need to say let me roll up the sleeves to dig a channel or build a bridge to get data from other system. 

In essence, the business users give the requirement and IT guys build the infrastructure to make it happening. API is the new tools IT guys use in the cloud world.

Regards,

George

entry.title: Re: Running T-code miro, how should i set the DRSEG-SGTXT value automatically
entry.content:
Use BTE : FI_BTE_PROCESS_00001120 and write the code in BTE like below;

LOOP AT t_bsegsub ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL ' <lfs_bsegsub>'.
   ' <lfs_bsegsub>'-sgtxt =  'Default Text'.
  ENDLOOP.
